item.title: Checking you have some data
item.description: In an earlier cheat sheet you should have created an empty project and linked in the sample ASSET data. If you didn't, then frankly you're bugger - so if I was you I'd go back and do it right now.

item.title: ASSET data files
item.description: ASSET breaks down the information required to run through a scenario into two separate file types: scenario files describe what's to be simulated, and control files direct ASSET in how to run the simulation. Whilst both types of file contain data stored in the textual <i>xml</i> data format, the ASSET working practice is that scenario files have the .asset file suffix (to help you to organise your data)

item.title: Open a scenario file
item.description: Right, let's start off with a scenario file. Double-click on the ForceProt.asset data file in the AssetData folder of your navigator. It will open in the central editor pane.

item.title: The ASSET XML editor
item.description: ASSET's xml editor uses a two-tab construct. At the foot of the editor pane you'll see two tabs, one named Design and the other named Source. The Design tab is a tree-oriented editor that gives you an overview of your scenario, the Source tab lets you get right down in the weeds.

item.title: Have a look at the scenario
item.description:
In the Design view, you'll see that the top-level element in our data is the tree, and this contains child elements that specify the time-step, the environment used for the simulation, and the participants in the simulation. In xml, these data structures are called elements, they're annotated in the design view with an e symbol. Data items in these elements are called attributes - which are annotated with a b symbol. To the right of the participants element you'll see some green text that specifies what types of element can be added to the participants element - in this case the list of platform types that can be specified. If you right-click on the Participants element and select Add Child you'll see a list of platform types that can be added - but we'll leave that for later. Open the participants element and you'll see it contains three surface vessels and a single ssk. Open the first surface vessel and you'll see it's called HVU. Attributes are edited with the Properties view. Open this using the Window/Show View/Properties menu, or clicking the Click to perform button below. Next, feel free to browse through the HVU child elements to view the data structures.

item.title: View a control file
item.description:
Ok, close the scenario file by clicking on the x symbol in the tab above it. Now, double-click on ForceProt.xml. When this opens you'll see it's a ScenarioController element that contains two children, a ScenarioGenerator (that describes how random variances should be applied to your scenario, plus an ObserverList that defines a series of control structures that listen to your running scenario - recording observations to file or interacting with the scenario itself.
. If you look into the ScenarioGenerator object you'll see it contains an element that defines multiple participants - 300 of the scenario element called SSK. It also varies their initial course, and where they start.
If you open the ObserverList you'll see it contains 6 observers that control how long the scenario runs for, producing a track plot image, producing Debrief plot files, plus indications of how to display/control detections.
